comment: TITLE:- Electro-Negativity <[]> Atomic Radii, Ionic Radii & Iso-Electronic Atoms <[]> Ionic & Covalent Bonds (intro) + Polar-Covalent (Brief) <[]>  Topics:-  1. ElectroNegativity     - Linus Pauling --> proposed the ideas of it. (Prof. J. Grossman talks about it @L09 of 5.111 2018ed)     - Here, Prof. Catherine @01:00 --> focuses more on the Ideas of DR. ROBERT. S. MULLIKEN (1896-1986)     - 𝝌 = ½( IE + EA )      - I had a Super Hard time understanding it, Because Prof: Cathy never talked about it enough before throwing off that Clicker question. >_< I think it's because prof. Cathy was expecting students to be able to tackle the Clicker Question using the Equation that she showed on the Board. But I had very strong doubt about it & I was denying that equation from the insides of my body & mind. I had to go check out the Lectures by Prof. J. Grossman over @5.111 OCW-2018. That helped me understand it properly  & Also this article:- https://lavelle.chem.ucla.edu/forum/viewtopic.php?t=81989#p363278  :cat-orange-whistling:      - Why should we care about Electro-Negativity @06:55       - Honestly, IMO, The example shown about this is really Bad.... It hardly gets you to understand "WHY ELECTRO-NEGATIVITY?", & Why not Electron-Affinity? :shrugg: :face-blue-wide-eyes:I think they produced such video anyway, because they really couldn't find any real world example of where to actually talk about this goddamn confusing Electro-Negativity term which from the dawn of time should have been called "Electron-Tight-enity" [refer to the ucla Link that I put above.]        - They weren't at all talking about Electro-Negativity. They were just casually discussing usage of HALOGENs.... & That, good people, can also be understood just as fine using the idea of Electron Affinity & Ionization energy alone. & I got confused in the process, Thinking that I am dumb >_<    2. Atomic Radi-i @13:55, Ionic Radii @17:00 Iso-Electronic Atoms @23:00     - 90% of Probability Cloud (a.k.a Electron Density) is inside that Radius :cat-orange-whistling:     - 𝑟 ∝ 𝑛²     - 𝑟 ∝ 1/𝒵     - 𝑟 = radius     - BUT     - E ∝ 𝒵²/𝑛²       [top/bottom is swapped now]    THE DOGS @27:11         &       𝕋𝕙𝕖 𝕄𝕚𝕝𝕝𝕚𝕠𝕟 𝔻𝕠𝕝𝕝𝕒𝕣 𝕋𝕒𝕜𝕖𝕒𝕨𝕒𝕪           BONDing = the thing between 2 Atoms & 2 atoms only       [SideNote By REY]     Molecule = Made-up of 1Bond or More :cat-orange-whistling:                             [SideNote By REY]  3. Ionic Bonds @29:30     - Catherine shows How can know if a Ionic Bond will form.... >_< :cat-orange-whistling:     - Coulombic Attraction between Ionic Atoms @33:25 4. Covalend Bonds (intro) @38:30 ===> Polar-Covalent Bond (the Idea) @46:30     - The GRAPH:- Distance v/s PE(IonicBond) @00:32  ==== "The Diagram of Attraction & Repulsion" ===+> It is better explained by Prof. Jeff. Grossman @L07 ending + L08 of 5.111 (2018 OCW)     - DISSOCIATION ENERGY a.k.a BOND STRENGTH ====> @42:10       - Which molecule has Stronger Bond? ====> @44:00  5. How many Bonds can an ELEMENT Make?     ====> Varies as per ELEMENT ====> Discussed in the next video in my KHEMEIA P2 playlist (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C0Qaf-UJ2XQ) 6. How the fuck does Molecules (with multiple Bonds) Look? In realiaty? Can we capture them with ElectronMicroscope? ====> (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C0Qaf-UJ2XQ) 7. What the fuck are Molecular Vibrations? In Reality? Can you Picture them in your mind? How does scientists think of it? ====> (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C0Qaf-UJ2XQ)     - All the Usage:- Also discussed in that video :cat-orange-whistling:
When she says that high electronegativity is due to high IE. It is wrong, it could very well be caused by high EA !

What are you even talking about? Human activity is by far the biggest contributor to climate change, nothing else comes even remotely close due to the huge amount of greenhouse gases we emit. Even implying otherwise, against the huge amount of literature that proves this is just being scientifically illiterate or worse.
@olcay8233  it seems that you are not aware of data. Study!

@adrianositizano  im literally a chemistry major specializing in environmental chemistry and the science behind how much we're contributing to climate change is very, very solid and super easy to understand. burning carbon heavy compounds emits carbon rich gasses which in turn makes it so that the heat coming in from the sun can't escape, thus creating changes in the climate. for someone to ignore such simple science they would either have to be paid by the industries that create this effect for monetary gain, or they would have to be influenced easily by the propaganda they pump out for again, monetary gain. whichever you are, i really don't care, but spreading misinformation about a topic that is currently killing people as we speak and might be a very catastrophic event for so many innocent lives is just a horrible, shameful thing to do. educate yourself.
@olcay8233  what can tell you, keep believing.

The Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program (UROP) is one of a host of experiential learning opportunities available to students at MIT. UROP cultivates and supports research partnerships between MIT undergraduates and faculty - whether you join established research projects or pursue your own ideas. https://urop.mit.edu/research-exploration/urop
